ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, I understand that this short discussion about target-based vs. non-target-based evolution may grow a bit off-topic, but I would love to take this

From: Nicolas Bredeche <nekonaute@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in
 digital organisms
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=331172310; y=eihzOlWbIuthpDY5HCFt5xIdht0vlXZtWyVnnN70RTV4QHWU
X-Yahoo-Profile: nekonaute


--f46d044516dd9f8a5104cbb7dbf6
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hi,

I understand that this short discussion about target-based vs.
non-target-based evolution may grow a bit off-topic, but I would love to
take this discussion a little further about the difference btw
objective-driven and environment-driven evolution.

(...)

> > I'm also not sure whether it's really accurate to say Avida is "not
> target-based." It's true that it's not as explicit as a single simple
> objective function, but the fact that there are several logical operations
> that explicitly give an advantage to organisms that execute them actually
> does create a form of objective-driven pressure. In other words, the
> creativity of evolution in Avida with such a priori human-defined rewards
> is to some extent hampered by the need to stay competitive on those
> arbitrary objectives. So I'd expect it to be closer to objective search
> (when used in that mode) than non-objective search, though somewhere on the
> continuum between them. I also understand that Avida as a platform doesn't
> have to be run with those rewards, but if I understand correctly they are
> traditional and used in this particular paper as well.
> >
>
> I agree with you. Avida is likely more towards non-objective search than
> target-based search, but probably not by that much. You'd likely get a
> stronger argument from Charles Ofria about it being more open-ended, but
> I've always thought that Avida (and all alife simulations) are still rather
> target-based. That's why I don't put too much stock in the argument that
> not having an explicit fitness function makes some alife simulations more
> interesting: I usually think they do have an explicit fitness function,
> it's just a complicated one that we don't understand as much as others.
>
 (...)

It seems to me that one additional property must be taken into account
about how the selection pressure is actually applied. On the one hand,
selection can be implemented as an user-defined metric used to compare and
rank individuals for selection/replacement, which is the classical way in
Evolutionary Robotics/Algorithms (incl. novelty search, ie. an explicit
function formulating an implicit objective - though of course the search
for novelty looks a lot like modelling the red queen). On the other hand,
selection can result from environmental pressure as it is the case with
TIERRA (and to less extent, to AVIDA, IMHO), where selection/replacement
does not depend on a performance value to be computed.

I agree with you both as AVIDA seems to stand inbetween as a performance
measure is actually computed (the metabolic function) but is not directly
used for selection/replacement. On the contraty, I always had the
impression that TIERRA was something more on the side of "true" natural
selection, environment-driven instead of target-based. Of course,
minimizing program size in TIERRA may be seen as the objective, but it is
not explicitly formulated compared to AVIDA's metabolic functions which
directly impact the duplication success (if i am not mistaken, as i am not
an AVIDA practitionner).

In a recent paper co-authored with Jean-Marc Montanier (presented at the
EPS workshop at ALIFE 2012), we summarized some work on environment-driven
evolutionary adaptation of swarm of epucks robots done in the Symbrion
swarm/modular robotic project, and we faced the problem as to where our own
work stands. We came up with some sort of (imperfect) classification as we
tried to position our own work wrt. traditional Evolutionary Robotics (ER),
Embodied Evolution (EE), ALIFE simulation about evolution (ALIFE). I just
extracted an up-to-date image of the table from the paper so you may find
it easily: check it
here<http://www.lri.fr/%7Ebredeche/pub/table-EPS2012.jpg>(EDEA is our
own method, forget it if you wish, it is not the point here).
Of course, this is not meant as a definitive table as frontiers are
somewhat blurred, as with the position of novelty search (which is also
environment-driven in some way, but still explicitly formulated) or AVIDA's
metabolic function (which also makes AVIDA task-driven). I'd be curious if
some of you have some feedback to provide on this global classification.

Cheers,

Nicolas

ps:  btw, i really enjoyed reading your paper Jeff, inspiring and clearly
written, as always :-)

--f46d044516dd9f8a5104cbb7dbf6
